Entries.info: The angle proportional gain. Helps to correct angle errors. Higher gain means smaller errors and faster response, but can lead to oscillations and overheating.
The angle integral gain. Helps to correct steady state angle errors. Higher gain means quicker suppression of steady state errors, but also increased oscillations, overheating, and faster windup.
The angle derivative gain. Helps to reduce overshoot oscillations. Higher gain means less overshoot from Kp and Ki, but can also introduce higher frequency oscillations and overheating.
The motor must receive a message within this amount of time. If it does not, it enters coast mode.
